comment.author: 29598412@N00
comment._content: The "Gov" is Oswald Wilson, governor of Oregon from 1911 to 1915. That would probably make "Mrs. Dunway" be Mrs Abigail Scott Duniway (or Dunway) who was real big in the suffrage movement in Portland, OR at that time. The big document could be the Equal Suffrage Proclamation she wrote at his request although this particular pic looks staged. The Only "Mrs Coe" I could find was Mrs Henry Clarke Coe, one a 1910 society page in the NYTimes where both women are mentioned (but in different articles) and in an 1917 article about the formation of a womens rifle corp where she is listed as President General of the National Society of New England Women. Apparently she too was big in women's causes at the time, but I can only guess if that's her.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks for the information. We'll add it to the source catalog.

comment.author: 11572312@N00
comment._content: The Atlanta Constitution (1881-2001) - Atlanta, Ga. Date:Mar 29, 1914 The governor of Oregon, Oswald West, will visit Atlanta in May and will address the citizens of Atlanta on the subject of Woman Suffrage and What it has done in the western states. Governor West comes by invitation... (name is West not Wilson)... Here is Wikipedia article about Women's Suffrage, it mentions Oregon going with the women's vote in 1912. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_women's_suffrage_in_the_... Here is this same picture posted to an article about Women's Suffrage in Oregon. It identifies photo as: Abigail Scott Duniway, with Governor Oswald West and Mrs. Viola M. Coe, signing Oregon's Equal Suffrage Proclamation. 11/30/1912 www.museumoftheamericanwest.org/explore/exhibits/suffrage...

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks for providing more information for us to add to the source catalog!

comment.author: 29598412@N00
comment._content: OMG, I knew it was West, but wrote Wilson.  How weird!

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Now we have a name from the other caption, Mrs. Coe seems likely to be the former Viola May Boley, married to a Dr. Henry Waldo Coe. See www.mandanhistory.org/biographiesak/henrycoe.html and files.usgwarchives.org/or/multnomah/bios/coemd359gbs.txt for biographies of him. books.google.com/books?id=NWlGAAAAMAAJ&pg=RA2-PA514&a..., published in 1911 suggests that she had an M.D. degree from the Women's Medical College of Chicago, but did not practice in Oregon after they moved there. books.google.com/books?id=ilVVAAAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA457&a... (from 1910) tells us a little more about her. She was a co-founder of the Home for Unemployed Women in Portland and wrote articles about noted women and foreign travel.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The same photo is also at: hdl.loc.gov/loc.mss/mnwp.150003 in the collection of photos from the Records for the National Women's Party
